metadata.titleEn: Geochronology and geochemistry of deep-seated enclaves in the middle part of the northern margin of North China
metadata.description: The data are mineral dating data, mineral isotope data, mineral major elements data, whole rock major and trace geochemical data and whole rock isotope data of rock xenoliths (amphibolite, basic granulite and garnet bearing neutral granulite) in the lower crust. Zircon U-Pb isotopic data were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, zircon Hf isotopic data were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and major mineral elements were obtained by electron probe analysis. The main and trace geochemical data of the whole rock were obtained by X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, respectively, and the whole rock isotopic data were obtained by thermal ionization mass spectrometry. Through the data obtained, the age and chemical composition of the deep crust in the region are limited, and the structure of the lower crust is reconstructed.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The name of the file is "UPB", which represents the mineral radiometric data. The file name "HF" represents mineral isotope data. The name of the file "wrmajtra" represents the major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock. The file name "SrNd" represents the whole rock isotope data. The name of the file is "minmaj", which represents the data of mineral major elements.

literatureList.titleEn: Geochronology and geochemistry of deep-seated crustal xenoliths in the northern North China Craton: Implications for the evolution and structure of the lower crust
literatureList.referenceEn: Su, Y.P., Zheng, J.P., Griffin, W., Huang, Y., Wei, Y., & Ping, X.Q. (2017). Geochronology and geochemistry of deep-seated crustal xenoliths in the northern North China Craton: Implications for the evolution and structure of the lower crust. Lithos, 292-293, 1-14.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics and methodologies used in collecting isotopic data from deep crustal xenoliths?
Feature Specification.Answer: laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, zircon U-Pb isotopes, zircon Hf isotopes, thermal ionization mass spectrometry, whole-rock Sr isotopes, whole-rock Nd isotopes

Interpretation.Question: How can the combination of mineral U-Pb and Hf isotopic data, along with whole-rock geochemical analyses, inform our understanding of the compositional and chronological evolution of deep crustal structures in the North China Craton?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of mineral U-Pb and Hf isotopic data, along with whole-rock geochemical analyses, allows researchers to determine the age and chemical composition of deep crustal rocks. U-Pb dating provides precise age constraints on zircon minerals, while Hf isotopic data offers insights into the source characteristics and evolution of these minerals. Whole-rock geochemical analyses, using both major and trace elements, further define the overall chemical makeup of the crustal rocks. Together, these data enable the reconstruction of the age and chemical evolution of deep crustal structures, offering a comprehensive view of the geological history and processes in the North China Craton.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes might lead to inaccuracies in the isotopic data obtained from deep crustal xenoliths using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inaccuracies in isotopic data could arise from factors such as laser ablation parameters, calibration of the mass spectrometer, matrix effects in the xenolith samples, and potential contamination during sample preparation and measurement processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon U-Pb isotope analysis on the accuracy and reliability of age determination in crustal studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon U-Pb isotope analysis can enhance the accuracy and reliability of age determination by providing precise mineral dating, essential for constraining the age of the deep crust. It allows for detailed insights into the temporal evolution and chemical composition of crustal structures, which is crucial for reconstructing lower crustal structures.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind collecting deep source xenolith geochemical and geochronological data in the context of reconstructing sub-crustal structures?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include determining the age and chemical composition of the deep crustal region, as well as reconstructing the structure of the lower crust. This is achieved through mineral dating, isotopic analysis, and geochemical data collection from xenoliths, providing insights into the region's geological history and processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in obtaining mineral isotopic data using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for analyzing zircon samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Mineral isotopic data is obtained by analyzing zircon samples through laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). This process involves using a laser to ablate a small portion of the zircon mineral, which is then ionized in the plasma. The resulting ions are measured by the mass spectrometer to determine isotopic ratios, such as zircon U-Pb isotopes for dating purposes, and zircon Hf isotopes for mineral isotopic data.
